txt.en: Talk to Mótsog and hear his tale
Hear the tale of Mótsog
Talk to Mótsog and hear his tale
Witness the betrayal of the Greymauls by the Orcs
Mótsog's tale is nearly complete.
'There can be no victory against it!'
'Flee! Flee!'
Mótsog's tale is nearly complete.
Mótsog's tale is nearly complete.

The words of Mótsog have painted the picture of a dwarf woman who will stop at nothing to rescue her husband and king. You can almost see her striding through the burning streets of Biriz-zahar, calling for Durin to answer her, as Mótsog's voice fades. The heat of the flames feels so real.
'Módvit... already slain?'

'Durin was brought in chains to the very summit of Biriz-zahar, where my people and their Orc-allies gathered to see the fallen king and make mock of him.\n\n'He suffered their taunting and their jests for many an hour, but I could see no sign of despair upon his face. I noted it even then.'
Mótsog has brought his tale near to its conclusion.
The army led by Ragna the Fierce climbed the unguarded stairs to the high places of Biriz-zahar.
Mótsog's tale is nearly complete.

'It was Ragna the Fierce, Durin's queen, who led them in secret across the river and to the base of Biriz-zahar. She was a mighty warrior and had slain Orc and Greymaul alike during the war, but now she found the gates of my city unguarded; too many of my folk desired to be present at Durin's defeat.\n\n'So it was that Ragna and her army entered the city unopposed. They found a stair to the heights and began to climb.'
'Who now has the advantage, Durin?'
'I, Mótsog, King of all the Dwarves, will take what is mine!'
'Climb, my warriors!'
'But an army cannot remain silent for long, and when Ragna's warriors reached the upper levels of the city, my warriors were made aware of their presence. They raced to engage the interlopers.'
'Your words will not save you, Durin.'
'Mótsog! We must set aside our differences, or all our people will be slain!'
'Save the king!'
'You will die here, and none will remember you.'
'For whom do you wield the Greymaul, my old friend?'
Mótsog's tale is nearly complete.
'In this moment of triumph, my Greymauls saw not the danger.'
'If we do not do this, our people will perish!'
Mótsog's tale is nearly complete.
'An army came by secret paths to free their captive king.'
'Our people, my friend.'
'Begone, worm! And never again trouble our folk!'

'Morgoth and his lieutenant Sauron had not been idle during the ten years of conflict between the dwarf clans. In secret they devised a plan by which Longbeard and Greymaul alike might be destroyed, and the dwarves swept entirely from Middle-earth.\n\n'And so it was that while Longbeard and Greymaul battled in the heights of my golden city, Sauron watched from afar. With malice afire in his heart, Morgoth's cruel servant sent a preordained signal to his legions.'
'But we were allies!'
'Longbeard fought Greymaul and Orc in the heights of Biriz-zahar, and the lanes ran with blood.'
DNT - Blah!
Mótsog continues his tale of the Sunder-battle.

'Despite the danger and the foes arrayed before her, Ragna the Fierce did reach the high places of Biriz-zahar, and she freed her husband and king from his bondage. But that was not enough for victory.\n\n'Durin picked up a fallen blade and joined the battle, but the Orcs were too many and the dwarves too divided; the Longbeards feared to present their backs to the Greymauls lest their foes take advantage of their distraction, and the Greymauls feared the same of the Longbeards. By the time Ragna freed Durin, two thirds of the dwarves had perished to flame and black steel. Sauron and his master, watching from afar, delighted in the carnage: the Orcs would win the day, and no dwarf would leave Biriz-zahar alive.'
Mótsog's tale is nearly complete.
Talk to Mótsog atop Biriz-zahar
Hear the tale of Mótsog
'We must find the king! Follow me, my warriors!'
'This way! My king, can you hear me?'
'Hurry!'
'Greymauls! To me!'
'What terror lies that way?'
'To the king! We cannot stand without him!'
Mótsog speaks of Sauron's betrayal of the Greymauls, and of Ragna's race through the blood-drenched city of Biriz-zahar.
Ragna the Fierce renewed her attempt to rescue her husband and king.
'You are trying to trick me!'
'I am the True Father, the King of All Dwarves!'
'Our people...? Even after so much death?'
'Hear me, you Greymauls.'
'Aye, Durin. We stand together!'
'No, you are Longbeards, as I am.'
'And so concluded the Sunder-battle, and with it the Greymaul Rebellion.'
'Do you not remember the lives you had?'
'I was defeated, but the dwarves survived.'
'Repent of your alliance with the Orcs!'
'It is beneath you! Such evil cannot be!'
'I know of your crimes, Mótsog.'
Climb the stairs to Biriz-zahar
'Etterfang feasted upon dwarves that day.'
Talk to Mótsog and hear his tale
'How many great warriors died to Thorog's claws in Biriz-zahar? I cannot say.'
Hear the tale of Mótsog
'But dragons were not the only evils sent by Sauron to my city.'
Talk to Mótsog and hear his tale
'It was the balrog called Askâdurs, wreathed in shadow and flame.'
'The fear of it drove dwarves screaming from the heights.'
Follow Ragna the Fierce through the burning city
'The fury of our blows was such that a great storm arose, and the mountain itself was sundered.'
'The flame of Askâdurs was quenched, and he fled.'
'But you know not of this, Durin, for it was known only to few.'
'We suffered grievous losses, but so too did Sauron: five dragons were slain at our hands.'
'Nine great dragons swept out of the northern skies, raining fire upon the mountainside.'
'Those that escaped would cower in fear of our weapons forevermore.'
Follow Ragna the Fierce through the burning city
'The Orcs turned their swords upon Longbeard and Greymaul alike.'
Instance: The Sunder-battle
